author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: In Rare Visit to White House Press Briefing, Biden Cautions Israel
description: The president suggested that Israel should consider alternative ways to retaliate against Iran.
content: A day after President Biden said the United States was “in discussion” about the possibility that Israel might strike Iran’s vast oil fields, he suggested that Israel should consider alternative ways to retaliate against Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Twohey, Danielle Ivory and Carson Kessler
title: ‘It Took Over Everything’: Stories of Marijuana’s Little-Known Risks
description: A growing number of marijuana users in the U.S. are experiencing severe health problems like these.
content: As marijuana legalization spreads across the country, people are consuming more of the drug, more often and at ever-higher potencies. Most of the tens of millions of people using marijuana, for health benefits or for fun, don’t experience problems. But a growing number, mainly heavy users, have experienced addiction, psychosis and other harmful effects, The New York Times found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Jobs and Oil Prices Are Keeping Markets on Edge
description: Friday’s jobs report could bolster the view that the American economy is holding steady, but an oil price shock could undercut that sense of calm.
content: With just over a month to go until Election Day, Friday’s jobs report, set to be published at 8:30 a.m. Eastern, has outsize importance. Investors will look for clues to what the Fed might do next with interest rates, as well as how the economy is doing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Disaster Funding Has Its Own Perils
description: Congressional leaders deferred a debate over sending federal money to respond to Hurricane Helene until after the election, delaying a potentially messy political fight.
content: When congressional leaders decided not to call lawmakers back from the campaign trail for an emergency session to fund relief and rebuilding efforts after Hurricane Helene, they cited practical considerations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Ismaeel Naar
title: U.S. Conducts Strikes Against Houthis in Yemen
description: The Houthis have been attacking ships in the Red Sea in solidarity with Hamas, and the U.S. attacks were aimed at securing international waterways.
content: The United States Central Command said on Friday that it struck Houthi targets in Yemen, including “Houthi offensive military capabilities,” in an effort to secure international waterways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Mark Zuckerberg Tries His Hand at Fashion
description: Et tu, Zuck?
content: Mark Zuckerberg would like us all to know that learning is best achieved through suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Risking a Friendship on the Dance Floor
description: Emil Weinstein and Dr. Alix Masters took things to the next level with Lil Jon and the East Side Boyz playing in the background.
content: On Feb. 16, 2019, Emil Ari Weinstein had a good feeling. He had just seen “Daddy,” a new play by Jeremy O. Harris, and was on his way to a dance party hosted by Papi Juice, an art collective in New York that celebrates queer and trans people of color. The performance of the play had gone well and the party was lively, but Mr. Weinstein couldn’t stop thinking about his friend, Dr. Alix Esther Masters, who was there with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Freeman
title: Brazil’s Largest Mafia Is Entering Politics. The Government Must Act.
description: For many Brazilians, the First Capital Command’s push into politics across the nation has been a shock.
content: The city of São Paulo, Brazil, is about to elect its next mayor, but the talk of the town is about a party that’s not on the ballot on Sunday: The “party of crime,” or as it’s formally known, the First Capital Command (P.C.C.).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Biden Will Allow Legal Permission to Lapse for Migrants From 4 Countries
description: The decision comes as political pressure mounts to cut down on programs that allow migrants to stay in the United States temporarily, even without a visa or green card.
content: The Biden administration said Friday it would allow the temporary legal permission for migrants from Cuba, Venezuela, Haiti, and Nicaragua to lapse, forcing hundreds of thousands of people to find other methods to stay in the country or face deportation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Her 8-Year-Old Drove Herself to Target and Became an Internet Star
description: Tangie Wilson was sleeping when her daughter Zoe sneaked out of the house and drove to the store. The tale of how it all unfolded is as relatable as it is incredible.
content: When Tangie Wilson’s 8-year-old daughter, Zoe, asked to use her iPad early one Sunday morning in September at their home in Bedford, Ohio, she assumed her child had settled into her room or on the couch with the device, so she went back to sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Dollar Is Too Strong for America’s Own Good
description: Weakening the dollar is a good idea. How to do it is another question.
content: The economist Richard Koo built pianos in Hong Kong for his father-in-law for a year and a half between college and graduate school. Now he is the chief economist of Nomura Research Institute in Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Harris Ad to Showcase Support of Liz Cheney and Other Republicans
description: Vice President Kamala Harris has been seeking to give Republicans who dislike the former president a permission structure to support her instead.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign will air a new ad in battleground states featuring endorsements from a retired general, former members of the Trump administration and former Representative Liz Cheney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Greenblatt
title: Once More Unto the Breach: A New Take on Henry V Showcases His Contradictions
description: In a comprehensive biography, the historian Dan Jones tries to reconcile the hero of legend with the complicated young monarch of reality.
content: Why read a new, 400-page biography of England’s King Henry V? Because, writes the best-selling historian and television journalist Dan Jones, while Henry ruled for less than a decade, “his reign is a case study in the art of leadership in a time of crisis, which feels especially apposite as I write these words today.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: The World’s Oldest Termite Mound Is 34,000 Years and Counting
description: Scientists recently found the planet’s longest continuously occupied termite colony in an arid region of South Africa. It dates to the time of the Neanderthals.
content: Last month, Michele Francis, an environmental scientist at Stellenbosch University in South Africa, relocated to central Connecticut only to discover that her new home showed signs of termite damage. When an exterminator suggested setting out traps, Dr. Francis demurred. “I wondered if I could persuade the termites to eat the trees around my house rather than the house itself,” she said. “I hold termites in high esteem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle and Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Lets Biden Plans on Mercury and Methane Move Forward
description: Republican-led states and industry groups argued that the Environmental Protection Agency had moved too fast and imposed onerous regulations.
content: The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would not stop the Biden administration from enforcing rules to reduce emissions of two pollutants: mercury, a hazardous neurotoxin, and methane, a potent greenhouse gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Heaps Scorn on Trump’s Latest Defense
description: Jimmy Kimmel said Donald Trump was “partially right” in denying interference in the 2020 election: “He tried to rig the election and failed to rig the election.’
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Friday Briefing: Israel Targets Hezbollah’s Remaining Leaders
description: Plus, a billion-dollar plan to protect trees.
content: Israel said it bombed an underground bunker where senior Hezbollah officials were meeting at midnight local time. The targets included Hashem Safieddine, the presumed successor to Hassan Nasrallah, the group’s recently assassinated leader, Israeli officials said. Here’s what we know about Safieddine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Euan Ward, Farnaz Fassihi, Victoria Kim and Michael Levenson
title: Israel Expands Attacks on Hezbollah as Iran Warns of Retaliation
description: Israel is drastically widening its fight against the Lebanese militant group that is backed by Iran, whose supreme leader said that “any strike on the Zionist regime is a service to humanity.”
content: Less than a week after Israel killed Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, Israeli warplanes bombarded areas south of Beirut around midnight on Thursday, this time targeting his presumed successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Their Uber Driver Crashed. A Pizza Order Unraveled Their Injury Lawsuit.
description: A New Jersey couple sued Uber after a crash left them severely injured. An appeals court ruled that they had agreed to settle disputes out of court when they used the Uber Eats app.
content: A New Jersey couple was heading home from dinner in an Uber in March 2022 when their driver T-boned another car, leaving them with serious injuries, including spine and rib fractures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
title: The Job Market Is Chugging Along, Completing a Solid Economic Picture
description: After months of wobbling, a fresh jobs report showed that hiring and wage growth are strong, aligning with other robust economic data.
content: For months, the economy has been like a jigsaw with one mismatched piece: Consumer spending has been holding up and overall growth has been solid, but the job market has looked treacherously wobbly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include cool fighter pilots, a feminist queen and urban turf wars.
content: “Born to Fly,” a flashy, adrenaline-pumping film from the Chinese director Liu Xiaoshi, has a lot in common with “Top Gun.” Like Tom Cruise’s Maverick, Lei Yu (Wang Yibo) is a cocky fighter pilot with big potential. Yu is sent to a flight school for exceptional test pilots, who fly next-generation planes to their breaking points. The academy then gathers data from the extreme flights to train combat fliers. Yu, again with echoes of Maverick, starts out declaring, “No one knows the limits better than I do,” before becoming a team player.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 4, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Oct. 4, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about new evidence disclosed in a court filing made public about Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election results, misstated the former position of Ronna McDaniel. She served as the chairwoman of the Republican National Committee, not the Republican National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: A More Working-Class British Cabinet, Still Seen as Out of Touch
description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s top team contains more lawmakers from poor backgrounds, and fewer from elite schools, than any in recent memory. Voters haven’t noticed.
content: Hot water was a luxury in the home where Angela Rayner, Britain’s deputy prime minister, was raised. Wes Streeting, the health secretary, was born to a single mother who pawned her jewelry to make ends meet. Racist skinheads shouted abuse at the young David Lammy, a Black Briton who is now foreign secretary, near his home in a deprived part of north London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Exploring Your Political Identity and Values: A How-To Guide for Our 2024 Coming of Age Contest
description: Four steps to figuring out what you want to say and how you would like to say it, with inspiration from 31 teen-created works across genres.
content: What can you show or tell us to help explain what it’s like to grow up in this political moment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: How States Are Enticing Employers to Help Their Workers Save for College
description: With college costs high, at least eight states now offer tax credits or deductions for employers that contribute to workers’ 529 accounts.
content: As higher education becomes ever more expensive, some states are giving employers incentives to contribute to 529 college savings accounts for their workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Rally in Michigan Dominated by More False Statements
description: Appearing for roughly 85 minutes onstage, the Republican nominee repeated false claims about the 2020 election and introduced a mischaracterization about disaster-relief money.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump held a rally on Thursday in the key battleground state of Michigan that was notable mainly for his continued false statements and exaggerations on a number of subjects as varied as the 2020 election and the federal government’s response to Hurricane Helene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Jenny Gross
title: Europe Raises Tariffs on China’s E.V.s, Confronting a Key Trade Partner
description: European Union officials say the duties are meant to protect the region’s automakers from what they say are unfair trade practices in China.
content: The European Union voted on Friday to impose higher tariffs on electric vehicles imported from China, risking tensions with an important trading partner in an effort to protect an industry crucial to Europe’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: At Least 16 Die as Floods Sweep Through Bosnia
description: A severe overnight rainstorm in the Balkans left several towns and villages flooded. Record summer temperatures had caused a drought that hampered the absorption of floodwaters.
content: A night of heavy rainfall left at least 16 people dead and large parts of southern Bosnia under water or smothered by landslides, the authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: It’s Not World War III. But Foreign Conflicts May Get Uglier Before Election Day.
description: Rarely do foreign crises and a presidential election collide like they have in the past few days.
content: Good evening! Tonight, my colleague David Sanger, a White House and national security correspondent, has a look at what the widening conflict in the Middle East might mean for the presidential campaign. Plus, a Times photographer explains what she saw in Georgia this week with Vice President Harris. — Jess Bidgood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: They Met For the First Time Twice
description: Rieanna Stewart remembered Devin Miller from a brief encounter three years earlier. And then: “We both left time and space,” Ms. Stewart said.
content: Devin Ellise Miller recalled first meeting Rieanna Katherine Stewart at a bar in Detroit in February 2022. But Ms. Stewart remembers it differently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Chayes
title: Democrats Have a Corruption Problem. They Can’t Keep Ignoring It.
description: For the sake of their electoral fortunes and the country, Democrats must show voters a plan to curb corruption — including within their own ranks.
content: For the past eight years and across two impeachment trials, the Democratic Party has defined itself in opposition to Donald Trump’s corruption, assailing the ways he abused the presidency for his own financial and political benefit. But with Mayor Eric Adams of New York fighting a federal corruption indictment, former Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey awaiting sentencing for a similar fraud and bribery scheme and numerous California officials sitting in federal prison, it’s hard to deny that corruption is a bipartisan problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: Researchers Find Cannibalized Victim of 19th-Century Arctic Voyage
description: A new study offers clues to a 179-year-old mystery that killed more than 100 explorers on the Franklin expedition in the Canadian Arctic.
content: Into the frozen fray they went, the explorer Sir John Franklin and his crew of 128 men, sailing from England in 1845 in search of the Northwest Passage. And there, in the unforgiving expanse of the Canadian Arctic, they perished. No one knows exactly what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Says the Election Will Be Fair. But He’s Not Sure It Will Be Peaceful.
description: President Biden’s remarks underscore the concerns in the government about the possibility of violence during or after the election.
content: President Biden said Friday he was not sure next month’s election would be peaceful if former President Donald J. Trump lost his bid for another term in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden and Gaya Gupta
title: Friend of Murdered Transgender Woman Says Seeking Justice Was Painful
description: Rasheen Everett strangled Amanda Gonzalez-Andujar in her Queens apartment in 2010. His first conviction was thrown out because of a judge’s error.
content: As a teenager in Bushwick, Brooklyn, Amanda Gonzalez-Andujar loved Halloween.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: A Death in Childbirth Raises New Questions About a Hospital
description: Bevorlin Garcia Barrios, 24, is the third woman to die during childbirth at Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn since 2020.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll explore deepening concerns over maternal health care at a Brooklyn hospital where three women have died during childbirth since 2020. We’ll also look at a hearing in the case of Daniel Penny, who choked Jordan Neely to death in a subway last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
title: In a Rare Sermon, Iran’s Supreme Leader Praises Oct. 7 Attacks as ‘Logical’ and Warns Israel
description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who led Friday prayers for the first time in years, called for pan-Muslim unity against Israel and the United States at a memorial service for Hassan Nasrallah.
content: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, led Friday prayers for the first time in almost five years, delivering a sermon during a memorial service in Tehran for Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in which he railed against Israel and warned of further retaliation, if necessary, for its actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Jobs Report Adds to Economic Momentum for Harris
description: Recent reports have shown inflation slowing and the economy growing at a robust clip. The Fed has also cut interest rates, bringing mortgage rates down.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris probably could not have hoped for a better run of pre-election economic data than what the United States has enjoyed over the last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Orange Beef Will Cure What Ails You
description: It’s takeout-style Chinese American cooking brought into your home kitchen, where you can get as creative as you’d like.
content: Good morning. The way things usually work for me this time of year: Weekdays are beautiful, crisp and clear. Guides I know text me at work with shots of beautiful fish caught by their grateful clients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Israel Expands Evacuation Warnings in Southern Lebanon After Renewed Strikes
description: Israeli soldiers were also waging a ground invasion in southern Lebanon targeting what military officials said were Hezbollah sites in the rugged border area.
content: Israel appeared to expand its military operations in Lebanon on Friday, issuing new evacuation warnings across the south and bombing a border crossing with Syria, hours after a series of airstrikes shook the outskirts of the Lebanese capital, Beirut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,204
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 5, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nostrant
title: Entire Chicago Education Board to Resign Amid Tensions Between Mayor and Schools Chief
description: Mayor Brandon Johnson has been at odds with the head of Chicago Public Schools over his plan to fill a $1 billion gap in the district’s budget.
content: All of Chicago’s board of education members announced their resignations on Friday amid tense disagreements between Mayor Brandon Johnson and the chief executive of Chicago Public Schools over the school district’s budget next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump’s False Claims About the Federal Response to Hurricane Helene
description: The former president falsely accused the Biden administration of spending disaster funding on migrants, neglecting areas that had voted for Republicans and ignoring a call from a Republican governor.
content: After Hurricane Helene battered several Southeastern states last week, former President Donald J. Trump wasted no time in criticizing President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris for the federal government’s response — often making false accusations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Bad Day? Here are 4 Ways to Turn It Around.
description: There’s still time to salvage it.
content: When I hit midlife, I discovered that you can pull a muscle in all kinds of new ways: sneezing, parking a car. And, as I found out last week, you can tweak your back just getting out of bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Joe D. Bryan, 84, Dies; His Murder Conviction Raised Troubling Questions
description: After serving 33 years in prison, he was released in the wake of a cascade of questions about the soundness of the forensic testimony against him.
content: Joe D. Bryan, a former high school principal who was released from prison in Texas after serving 33 years for a murder conviction based on expert testimony that was later discredited, and whose claims of innocence drew intense media scrutiny, died on Sept. 22 at his home in Houston. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Ana Swanson
title: For Companies in China, Pulling Out of Xinjiang Poses ‘Messy Dilemma’
description: Beijing’s investigation of the parent of Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger, which stopped buying goods from Xinjiang, has put global firms in a difficult position.
content: An investigation by China of an American clothing retailer has escalated concerns among foreign companies about their dependence on Chinese supply chains and the future of their operations in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle and Adam Liptak
title: Death Penalty, Nuclear Waste and More: Supreme Court Rounds Out Coming Term
description: Three cases all stem from the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, which often finds itself to the right of the Supreme Court.
content: The Supreme Court on Friday added more than a dozen cases to the docket for its new term, which begins next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Would You Want to Be a Child Star?
description: Jenna Ortega tells Times readers about the joys and the challenges of stardom at a young age. What can we learn from her experience?
content: Have you ever dreamed of being a child star?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Yazidi Woman Taken Captive by ISIS Has Been Rescued in Gaza, Israel Says
description: She was returned to her family in Iraq after a complex operation involving the United States, Jordan and others, the Israeli military said.
content: The Israeli military said on Thursday that it had rescued a 21-year-old Yazidi woman who had been held in captivity in the Gaza Strip after being captured by ISIS in Iraq as a child more than a decade ago, describing the operation as a “complex operation” involving the United States, Jordan and others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Britain Backs Plan to Store Carbon Dioxide Under the Sea
description: Two proposals in Northern England, led by the energy giants BP and Eni, aim to establish an industry in burying emissions from industrial plants.
content: The British government said Friday that it would back two large proposals to capture carbon dioxide emissions from industrial plants and bury the gas beneath the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Richard Mayhew, Painter of Abstract Landscapes, Dies at 100
description: He drew from his Black and Native American heritage, as well as his own memory, to find an emotional resonance behind the beauty of nature.
content: Richard Mayhew, a painter of Black and Native American heritage who was known for his explosively colorful abstract landscapes — he called them “mindscapes” — that traced the emotional contours of nature as well as his forebears’ historical relationship to the land, died on Sept. 26 at his home in Soquel, Calif., on the northern coast. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Reporter Asks Biden if He Would Reconsider Dropping Out of the Race
description: President Biden, who reluctantly surrendered his bid for a second term, has wanted to be president for most of his adult life.
content: He was almost out the door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: A Rest, a Reset and a Thanks for the Banter
description: After more than 350 editions, we are putting this newsletter on pause, with the editor who opened the Australia bureau departing and his successor set to arrive.
content: Nearly eight years ago, as I opened a new Australia bureau for The New York Times, I tried to imagine what a weekly newsletter from and about the country would aim to do: add some insight and perspective to email inboxes; connect with new readers in a conversational tone; guide people to New York Times coverage they might have overlooked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Bucking Trends, an Opera Company in Atlanta Is Growing
description: Under the leadership of Tomer Zvulun, Atlanta Opera powered through the pandemic, has tripled its budget and is producing ambitious work.
content: Walking through a repurposed industrial space in Atlanta one recent afternoon, Tomer Zvulun gestured toward a cafe table in the middle of a wraparound stage covered in graffiti.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman and Edward Wong
title: Hamas Leader Is Holding Out for a Bigger War, U.S. Officials Say
description: Yahya Sinwar is increasingly fatalistic, has blocked a cease-fire deal and, so far, been frustrated that Hezbollah and Iran have not come to his aid, officials said.
content: The leader of Hamas, Yahya Sinwar, has become fatalistic after nearly a year of war in Gaza and is determined to see Israel embroiled in a wider regional conflict, U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: These Are Boom Times for ‘Degrowth’
description: The term has recently begun taking root in popular culture and policy.
content: There’s long been one mantra in mainstream economics: Growth is good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Cuccinelli
title: The Supreme Court Should Stop the Glossip Execution
description: When prosecutors admit they were wrong in a death penalty case, courts should listen.
content: Nearly 90 years ago, in a case involving prosecutorial misconduct, the Supreme Court laid down its view of a prosecutor’s duty, one that has been widely repeated in court decisions ever since. The prosecution’s interest in a criminal prosecution, the court wrote succinctly, “is not that it shall win a case, but that justice shall be done.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lewis Gordon
title: Extreme Weather Gives Video Games a Powerful Adversary
description: Designers are increasingly able to render weather conditions as not just evocative visual effects but phenomena that physically affect the player.
content: The storms start off small in the vehicular survival game Pacific Drive. Raindrops fall on the windshield, as lightning cracks ominously in the distance. In a few minutes, the pristine Olympic Peninsula will shake with nature’s full terrible force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Economy Looks Strong After the Latest Jobs Report
description: Also, Trump is returning to the site where he was shot. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: The American labor market, which for months has worried even some optimistic economists, looked in remarkably good shape today after the government released a new employment report. Businesses added 254,000 jobs last month, far outpacing expectations. The unemployment rate declined to 4.1 percent and wage growth remained strong.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Brazil’s ‘Elegant’ Idea Could Save Tropical Forests and Generate Returns
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 4, 2024
content: “Everybody’s saying, look, in principle, this is crazy. But it’s crazy in a kind of interesting way.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘The Franchise’ Review: Cutting Marvel Down to Size
description: A new HBO comedy takes a jaundiced look at the making of a second-rate superhero film.
content: The new HBO series “The Franchise” satirizes the making of a superhero movie by a fictional movie studio that is Marvel in all but name. (The actual fictional name is Maximum Studios.) Warner Bros. Discovery, HBO’s parent, is Marvel’s bitter rival in the superhero field, so you might expect the show to offer an extra measure of savage mockery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman, Nate Cohn, Olivia Natt, Mooj Zadie, Michael Simon Johnson, Brendan Klinkenberg, Paige Cowett, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Four Weeks to Go
description: With Kamala Harris and Donald Trump locked in the tightest of races, who will come out on top? Watch or listen to our political round table on the 2024 election.
content: With Election Day fast approaching, polls show the race between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump to be the closest in a generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman, Theodore Schleifer and Michael Gold
title: Trump Falsely Promotes Endorsement From Banker Who Hasn’t Endorsed Him
description: As the campaign reaches its final month, the Republican nominee is intensifying his pattern of making false and outlandish statements.
content: Donald J. Trump announced what would have been groundbreaking news on Wall Street, in a post on his social media website, Truth Social, on Friday afternoon. At 1:56 p.m., Mr. Trump published, alongside a siren emoji, a claim that he’d been endorsed by America’s most influential banker, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, Jamie Dimon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Decide Whether Mexico Can Sue U.S. Gun Makers
description: The justices will consider whether a 2005 law that gives gun makers broad immunity applies in the case, which accuses them of complicity in supplying cartels with weapons.
content: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether Mexico may sue gun manufacturers in the United States for aiding in the trafficking of weapons used by drug cartels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolina Gelen
title: 3 Warming Dishes for Crisp Fall Days
description: Carolina Gelen, a cookbook author and video personality, shares cozy vegetable recipes from her childhood in Romania.
content: I remember the first time my mother allowed me to bake by myself: I must’ve been 6 or 7 when I made poppy seed-coated pretzel bagels. Of course, I forgot the salt in the dough, and they ended up a little bland. But I had found my passion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Teenagers on What Has Shaped Their Political Beliefs and Values
description: Ahead of the 2024 Election, we invited teens to explore their political identities and tell us how they have come to believe what they believe.
content: This fall, we are asking teenagers around the country and the world to explore their political and civic identities, values and beliefs and discuss them with others in our Election 2024 Student Conversation Forums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lana Bortolot
title: $650,000 Homes in Nova Scotia
description: Three takes on a water lifestyle in Canada’s eastern province: A shingled home by the bay, a chic cabin and a contemporary bungalow.

The apparent point was to warn New Yorkers that if they did not back his bid for re-election, the city would reprise its racist past, denying another Black mayor a second term. Mr. Dinkins lost his re-election effort to a race-baiting Rudy Giuliani, while the most serious threats to an Adams win — beyond a criminal prosecution — are coming from the progressive left and include candidates like Zellnor Myrie, a Black state senator with immigrant parents.

The outcome of the race could determine control of the chamber, and both parties are spending in accordance with the high stakes. American Crossroads began airing this particular spot in late September, according to AdImpact.

title: Jean Hanff Korelitz on ‘The Sequel’
description: The writer discusses her follow-up to her best-selling 2021 novel “The Plot.”
content: In 2021, the novelist Jean Hanff Korelitz had a hit with “The Plot,” a book that was partly a mystery, partly a thriller and entirely a delicious sendup of the publishing industry. It told the tale of a once-promising writer, Jacob, who steals somebody else’s story idea and reaches undreamed-of levels of success before things go very badly for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Does Your Facial Hair Make You Feel?
description: We want to hear about how women’s experiences of having visible facial hair impact their day-to-day.
content: Many women have visible facial hair. It can be a part of our appearances from a young age or can increase as we get older. Sometimes it’s caused by hormone imbalances, but in most cases it’s simply a part of life. But despite its prevalence, some women feel shame around it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Pentagon Debate: Are U.S. Deployments Containing the Fighting, or Inflaming It?
description: Military officials discuss whether sending more force to the Middle East is helping to prevent a much wider war, or emboldening Israel.
content: As the Israeli offensive in Lebanon expands to include ground incursions and intensifying airstrikes, senior Pentagon officials are discussing whether the enhanced U.S. military presence in the region is containing a widening war, as they had hoped, or inflaming it.

title: DNA Reveals the Origin Stories of America’s Captive Tigers
description: Scientists have wondered if the many captive tigers in the United States could one day help restore the species in the wild.
content: In 2020, the Netflix documentary series “Tiger King” introduced the world to America’s large population of captive tigers. content: It was the role John Amos had worked toward his entire acting career. For three seasons, to many accolades and impressive ratings, Amos played the patriarch, James Evans Sr., on “Good Times.” The character was hardworking, earnest and serious-minded — traits largely unseen in Black television characters up to that point in the mid-1970s. And “Good Times” was a hit, part of a string of sitcom successes from the executive producer Norman Lear.

content: There are just under two months left before the official Atlantic hurricane season ends in November, and with millions of people across the Southeast United States still assessing the damage of Hurricane Helene and two more storms churning at sea, experts are warning it isn’t over yet. It may even last into December.

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Corey Schreppel and Diane Wong
title: Can California Regulate A.I.? + Silicon Valley’s Super Babies + System Update!
description: “In the United States, we have 50 laboratories of democracy and they’re called states.”
content: On Sunday, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California vetoed Senate Bill 1047, an A.I. safety bill that would have curtailed the growth of the technology. What received a lot less attention were the 18 other important A.I. bills he signed into law over the past month. We walk through what is in them and what they mean for the rest of the country. Then, The Information’s Julia Black joins to discuss the baby craze that’s sweeping Silicon Valley, including investment in some wild new fertility technologies. And finally, it’s time for a system update! We get into OpenAI’s massive fund-raising deal and the senator who hopped on a call with a “deepfake” former Ukrainian official.

title: 5 Picture Books About Space, From the Sublime to the Silly
description: Works by Ada Limón and Peter Sís, Randy Cecil, Lucy Ruth Cummins and more depict the poetry, wonder and droll humor inspired by the great beyond.
content: These are lines from a poem by Ada Limón that has been engraved on Europa Clipper, the space probe NASA will launch on Oct. 10, if all goes well. (One suspects the two American astronauts now enjoying an unplanned stay on the International Space Station will not be holding their breaths.) Limón, the United States poet laureate since 2022, may give humanity too much credit when it comes to our capacity for constant awe, but I suppose positive thinking is part of the job description when you are commissioned to write a poem that will drift around the cosmos for eons and could serve as our calling card. title: The Economy Is at a Hinge Moment
description: The economist Jason Furman discusses the economic fights that the next presidential administration will face.
content: We have hit a hinge moment in the economy. For the past few years, there has been one problem on policymakers’ minds: inflation. But in mid-September, the Federal Reserve called an end to that era when it cut interest rates by half a percentage point. Inflation, it was saying, is no longer the problem. It has come down from around 9 percent annually to around 2.5 percent. But unemployment is creeping up again. There are some signs of economic stress. Having spent the past year cooling the economy down, the Fed now feels it’s both safe and necessary to heat it back up, at least a bit.
